text: Marshall, Houston, 1935. In times of racial segregation in the United States, Professor Melvin B. Tolson (Denzel Washington) from Wiley College led a group of African-American students to form an invincible debate team that toured across the country https://buff.ly/2oHiBEk pic.twitter.com/bU6EFUeh1Y
Today's United States African American historical fact: Today in 1954 U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Brown vs. Board of Education of Topeka that racial segregation in public schools is unconstitutional.

African-American civil rights movement was a human rights movement that enclosed groups and social movements to accomplish its goal of ending legalized racial segregation and discrimination laws in the United States. # jmsshpa10 # protest # history

Day 8: Thurgood Marshall was the first African-American to serve on the United States Supreme Court. He utilized the judiciary to champion equality for African Americans. In 1954, he won the Brown v. Board of Education case, in which ended racial segregation in public schools. pic.twitter.com/6Y6dKZmb2p

Thurgood Marshall was the first African American appointed to the United States Supreme Court. In 1954, he argued & won the Brown v. Board of Education case which helped end racial segregation in public schools. # BlackHistoryMonth # HISDlibrariesNOW # bhmfactoftheday

The very first African-American United States Army Air Force aviators are known as the Tuskegee Airmen. They fought for the first time in World War II, at a time when racial segregation was still in place in the United States. pic.twitter.com/nzXxAnPepy
